title: Which word seems the same as the other but has a different meaning? - Quora
tags: English Word Definitions, Terminology, and Jargon

response.answer_text: Going by different dictionary definitions, the simplest words (like set and do and in and up) are the ones with the largest number of different meanings. The word mole shows how a single spelling can cover words with different meanings but the same etymology, or words with different etymologies, and even words with different pronunciations. Three words with different meanings but the same etymology and pronunciation:mole, pronounced MOHL, is a darkish spot on the skin. It comes from a Proto-Germanic root that means something like *mailan "spot, mark”.mole, pronounced MOHL, smallish mammal that burrows in gardens. It has the same etymology as the skin spot.mole, pronounced MOHL, is a spy or plant that has figuratively burrowed into an organization. It’s exactly the same word as the mammal and the spot in terms of etymology and pronunciation, but it has a different meaning.Different etymologies from the above, but the same pronunciation:A mole, pronounced MOHL, is an abnormal mass caused by an non-viable fertilized ovum. Its meaning and etymology are unrelated to the preceding, having descended over 600 years from the Middle English and ultimately from the Latin mola, meaning millstone.A mole, pronounced MOHL, is a breakwater. Its meaning and etymology are unrelated to the preceding, having descended over 500 years ago from the Middle French môle, previously from Old Italian molo, from Latin moles, meaning mass or exertion.A mole, pronounced MOHL, is a unit of molecular quantity. Its meaning and etymology are unrelated to the preceding, having been coined in 1900 in German (Mol, short for Molekül).Different etymology and pronunciation from the above:mole, pronounced MOH-lay, is a sauce usually made with poblano peppers and, sometimes, chocolate. Its spelling is identical, but its pronunciation and etymology are completely unrelated to all of the preceding moles.

Bear….Can mean to bear the weight of something heavy, but is also the same spelling for the Bear animal, or even when we say to 'bear' the truth. Depending if we you are talking about the actual spelling of the word being the same, but meaning different things, or the sound of the word, but being spelt different ways. Bare spelt differently means, naked, or sparse. The word there sounds the same but is spelt differently for each meaning. There… Go over there. There is one place left. There are a great deal of possibilities. They're… They're over there in the corner. They're is an abbreviation for 'they are', but pronounced the same. Their… This item belongs to their parents. This is their house. Their is used as a item of possession that belongs to someone. Another example can be the word one…Which can be the number 1, or in conversation, he was the only one available. Or we can speak to one another… Whereas won, spelt differently, but sounds the same, is to describe something that has been gained, such as he/she won a medal, or won the jackpot etc.
